title: Bruce McAvaney, 66, puts his opulent Adelaide beachside home on the market for $2.45million
text:
Advertisement

He has temporarily relocated to Sydney to work on the Tokyo 2020 Olympics coverage next year.

And ahead of the international sporting event, Bruce McAvaney is selling his palatial Glenelg South home in Adelaide, which he has shared with his TV producer wife Anne Johnson for the last two decades.

The 66-year-old is hoping the million dollar home, which provides unobstructed views of the ocean on South Esplanade, will bring between $2.45 and $2.69 million, and he has listed it with Harris Real Estate.

For sale! Bruce McAvaney has put his palatial Glenelg South home (pictured) in Adelaide, which he shared with his TV producer wife Anne Johnson for the last two decades, on the market

Prime position! Bruce is hoping the home, which provides unobstructed views of the ocean on South Esplanade (pictured), will bring between $2.45 and $2.69 million, and he has listed it with Harris Real Estate

Speaking to The Advertiser, the Channel Seven personality said the luxury property has hosted a number of prominent sports commentators and athletes over the years, although he wouldn't specify who exactly.

'We entertained a lot more when we were a bit younger. Every year we had barbecues for groups of visiting commentators and athletes,' Bruce said.

Iconic sportscaster: Bruce McAvaney, 66 (pictured), is selling his Glenelg South home because he has temporarily relocated to Sydney to work on the Tokyo 2020 Olympics coverage next year

Ample living space! The million dollar property has two additional living and lounge areas - one of which has a fireplace

Culinary dream! The updated kitchen comes with all the mod cons and new appliances including an integrated fridge/freezer

He went on to say the sale will be somewhat bittersweet given that the home has provided such fond memories, but he added he intends to move back to Adelaide following his commentating stint for the Olympics.

'We will miss the community for the few months that we're relocating to Sydney. But what we will miss the most is hearing the ocean, even when it's stormy, it's spectacular. We can wake up in the morning and clearly see dolphins swimming while we're still lying in bed,' he said.

The four-bedroom home features an open-plan living, dining and kitchen area, as well as a private lounge and living room, three bathrooms, a laundry and an outdoor entertainment area, complete with patio and stone oven.

Private sanctuary! The master bedroom comes with lounge and balcony access, as well as a walk-in robe and full bathroom

Rest and rejuvenate! The luxury home has three bathrooms, which can adequately accommodate a large family

Plenty of space! The palatial four-bedroom residence features an open-plan living, dining and kitchen area

The property also boasts a well-sized boat shed for the would-be skipper, which is currently being used as a home gym, but there is plenty of space to accommodate up to five cars or small vehicles.

According to the real estate agent, the home's prime position next to the ocean will be a major drawcard for many potential buyers, who will likely see the property as a 'peaceful sanctuary', just a short distance from the CBD.

Selling agent Karen Dorman said the property would make an ideal home for a professional couple, someone who is looking to downsize, or a family interested in buying a weekend retreat.

'There's also a potential interstate market, some people could look at it as a weekender,' she said.

Lots to offer! The home also boasts a private lounge and living room area, three bathrooms and a laundry and an outdoor area
